physDesc.p: This letter is six pages long (seq. 4-9). It is typed on what seems to be notebook paper, which is torn in the bottom right-hand corner of the first page, and on the left side of the paper for the rest of the pages. There are several places where the text runs off the page on the right margin. The words "John Gould" are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: After I wrote to you yesterday I had a telephone message from Mr. Greenslet of Houghton Mifflin Company to say that they have definitely accepted your book. I hurriedly added the thing in a postscript and sent off the letter but did enter into details. Now here is the arrangement I have made for you which I hope you will approve. Ferris Greenslet has conceived the idea, pushed thereto largely by many criticisms against the way publishers treat modern poetry, to issue a series of small books in paper covers at the price of fifty cents each that they may reach everybody. He intends to be very careful and only have the very best poetry in this series. Of course his may not always agree with ours, as I think it is possible he may not always consider best poetry what we consider so, for one volume and our anthology for another. I believe he intends to have something of Lawrence Binyon’s for another volume, and whatever we may personally think of Lawrence Binyon he has sufficient good standing to have his name carry weight and dignity. I think another volume is going to be a collection of all the translations which Lafcadio Hearn made from Japanese poetry which are scattered through his writings and have never been collected before. You will see therefore from the start it is going to be rather an unusual and interesting series. I think I know enough of the situation to feel that any book issued in this series will stand just about as much chance of succeeding with the public as any book issued separately. I think therefore it is the best possible way for your book and our anthology to appear.

The terms I have agreed to are that he shall publish the book at his own expense but he will then keep the proceeds up to the amount of what he spent in publishing, and give you ten percent of the proceeds of all the sales. This is not a very brilliant arrangement, monetarily, but considering the great difficulty in persuading any publisher to take poetry and the utter indifference of the public, which I must say largely justifies the publisher, and the almost complete lack of sale for books of any kind except war books at the moment, I am sure that this is as good an arrangement as any one could have made for your book. Of course if you do not like any of this the contract is not yet signed (naturally, as I have not signed it) and you can withdraw from the transaction if you want to, but I can assure you that the Houghton Mifflin Company are the most honest publishers that you will find in America.

I did not offer your book to Macmillan as I knew they were over stocked with poetry but as you know I did offer it to Mosher and also put out a feeler in that regard to it was refused. Macmillans turned down our anthology largely, I think, on account of Ezra writing them an insulting letter about the advertisement of my book, and they told me with great vigor that they did not wish to be connected with the "group." Houghton Mifflin, on the other hand are anxious to be connected with the group as you see from their being willing to print your book and the anthology. I think it is the best publishing proposition for poetry I have heard of for a long time and I believe that with books at fifty cents and a big publishing house like Houghton Mifflin Company behind it will have a very great chance to gain the popular ear.

They kick at Hueffer’s "Heaven" for the anthology. In fact their acceptance of that book depends upon the removal of that poem and something else substituted less alien to the puritan susceptibilities of most of the partners. I will talk to you about this on Tuesday. In the mean time I have written to Richard and asked him what he thinks of it and to tell him that I think the only chance of publishing in a first class house is this one. I think it is better to sacrifice one poem than to have to take the book to a small firm like Boni’s. I have not put your preface in the book. I am afraid that it would not get people to read the book, I think it would antagonize them to start with. I think some sort of preface is an excellent thing, but I think you should assume that your readers are in sympathy with you. They must be in some sort of sympathy, if only curiosity, or they would never have bought the book, and I do not think it is good policy to kick the in the preface, but again we can talk this over on Tuesday.

I am only writing you this that you may know just where you stand. Of course you know that this whole series will be handled by Constable’s in England. I believe it to be a very excellent publishing venture.

I am terribly doubtful whether these letters will ever reach you. I am sending them to the main American Express office as I have not the slightest idea where else to send them and you said American Express in your letter. I do hope you will give me a more definite address before long because I feel quite at sea as to your whereabouts. I leave here on Monday as I wrote you Tuesday and go to the Hotel St. Regis, Fifth Avenue, where you can get me either by letter or telephone. Looking forward very much to Tuesday night, believe me.
